citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The following veterinary concerns were noted during the inspection:
A female Djungarian hamster was seen with significant swelling of the upper and lower left eyelids, such that the eye
could not be opened. There is a mild amount of clear discharge present and redness throughout the eyelids, though the
rest of the animal appeared normal. While husbandry has been performed routinely, facility records most recently
document that these animals were scanned for sickness on November 11, 2024.
Two "Skinny guinea pigs" (one is black and white, and the other one is black and tan) that arrived at the facility on
November 12, 2024, housed in lane 4, cage rack L of the guinea pig area, are both found to be in thin body condition with
their backbones easily observed. Also, the black and white guinea pig has multiple rounded, crusting skin lesions over the
back and neck. Per a facility representative, these animals had already received their daily observations this morning and
these issues have not been noted at this morning's daily observation or since their acquisition two days ago.
In another enclosure in Lane 4, a black "Skinny guinea pig" is observed with multiple healing scratches across its back
starting behind its shoulders, continuing down its back to across its rump, with associated scabbing that was not
previously noted on daily observation logs including this morning's daily observation that had already occurred.
These conditions were not identified by the facility and thus the attending veterinarian had not yet been contacted, nor
had appropriate veterinary care been administered. Failure to adequately observe animals for unmanaged health
concerns may delay care and cause undue pain, discomfort, or stress. The facility must maintain a more comprehensive
method to perform daily observations of all animals to identify problems and to assure direct and timely communication
with the attending veterinarian.
Upon recognition of these animals' conditions by the inspectors, the animals were transferred to another area for care and
monitoring and examination by the veterinarian.
Correct by November 18, 2024.

In the bird building containing the recently weaned parakeets, Inspectors noticed one blue and black parakeet outside of
its enclosure. The parakeet was seen on the bottom of the metal rack sleeping. Birds that escape their primary enclosures
could injure themselves, spread diseases, or get lost in the building. Primary enclosures must be constructed and
maintained so that they contain the birds securely.
To be corrected by: November 19, 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with Facility Representative.
Additional Inspectors:
Lisa Ekman, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER
Jason Sifkarovski, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.40(b)(3)  Direct Repeat
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
The following veterinary concerns were noted during the inspection: 
 
A female Djungarian hamster was seen with significant swelling of the upper and lower left eyelids, such that the eye 
could not be opened. There is a mild amount of clear discharge present and redness throughout the eyelids, though the 
rest of the animal appeared normal. While husbandry has been performed routinely, facility records most recently 
document that these animals were scanned for sickness on November 11, 2024.  
 
Two "Skinny guinea pigs" (one is black and white, and the other one is black and tan) that arrived at the facility on 
November 12, 2024, housed in lane 4, cage rack L of the guinea pig area, are both found to be in thin body condition with 
their backbones easily observed. Also, the black and white guinea pig has multiple rounded, crusting skin lesions over the 
back and neck. Per a facility representative, these animals had already received their daily observations this morning and 
these issues have not been noted at this morning's daily observation or since their acquisition two days ago. 
 
In another enclosure in Lane 4, a black "Skinny guinea pig" is observed with multiple healing scratches across its back 
starting behind its shoulders, continuing down its back to across its rump, with associated scabbing that was not 
previously noted on daily observation logs including this morning's daily observation that had already occurred.  
 
These conditions were not identified by the facility and thus the attending veterinarian had not yet been contacted, nor 
had appropriate veterinary care been administered. Failure to adequately observe animals for unmanaged health 
concerns may delay care and cause undue pain, discomfort, or stress. The facility must maintain a more comprehensive 
method to perform daily observations of all animals to identify problems and to assure direct and timely communication 
with the attending veterinarian.  
 
Upon recognition of these animals' conditions by the inspectors, the animals were transferred to another area for care and 
monitoring and examination by the veterinarian. 
Correct by November 18, 2024. 
3.153(a)(1)(iii)

Primary enclosures. 
In the bird building containing the recently weaned parakeets, Inspectors noticed one blue and black parakeet outside of 
its enclosure. The parakeet was seen on the bottom of the metal rack sleeping. Birds that escape their primary enclosures 
could injure themselves, spread diseases, or get lost in the building. Primary enclosures must be constructed and 
maintained so that they contain the birds securely. 
 
To be corrected by: November 19, 2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with Facility Representative. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Lisa Ekman, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER 
Jason Sifkarovski, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

species.common: DJUNGARIAN / RUSSIAN WINTER WHITE DWARF HAMSTER
